title: Repurposing of waste PET by microbial biotransformation to functionalized materials for additive manufacturing
reasoning: The abstract mentions that the biotransformation of waste PET can produce novel 3D printing materials as replacements for acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS). It also states that these approaches potentially enable the manufacturing of environmentally friendly degradable or higher-value high-performance polymers, implying safety advantages over conventional materials like ABS, which contains acrylonitrile. Therefore, it clearly indicates a safer alternative to acrylonitrile-containing materials.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to acrylonitrile. It only mentions acrylonitrile butadiene styrene as a material replacement in 3D printing without discussing toxicity, persistence, bioaccumulation, or other hazards.

title: Wastewater-Based Epidemiology (WBE): Potential Application for Assessing the Use of Conventional and New Generation Tobacco and Nicotine Products
reasoning: The abstract discusses the replacement of combustible cigarettes (CCs), which expose users to acrylonitrile, by tobacco-free nicotine products such as nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) products and electronic cigarettes (ECs). It highlights that these tobacco-free products are gradually replacing tobacco products that are the main source of acrylonitrile exposure, implying a safety advantage by reducing exposure to acrylonitrile. Thus, NRT products and ECs are presented as safer alternatives to acrylonitrile-containing tobacco products.
alternatives: nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) products; electronic cigarettes (ECs)

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to acrylonitrile. It only mentions acrylonitrile as a combustion product indicator measured in wastewater but does not describe any toxicity, persistence, bioaccumulation, or other hazards.

title: Acute health effects of desktop 3D printing (fused deposition modeling) using acrylonitrile butadiene styrene and polylactic acid materials: An experimental exposure study in human volunteers
reasoning: The abstract compares acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS) and polylactic acid (PLA) in terms of emissions and health effects. It reports that PLA is low-emitting and ABS is high-emitting, with ABS exposure causing higher levels of exhaled nitric oxide and increased indisposition and odor nuisance. This suggests PLA has a safety advantage over ABS, which contains acrylonitrile, indicating PLA as a safer alternative.

harms: eosinophilic inflammation from inhaled ultrafine particles
target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text explicitly mentions a slight relative increase in exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) after exposure to acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS) emissions, which might be due to eosinophilic inflammation from inhaled ultrafine particles. Additionally, indisposition and odor nuisance were increased for ABS exposure. No other explicit harms or hazards related to acrylonitrile are stated.

CHEMICAL HARM: eosinophilic inflammation from inhaled ultrafine particles, indisposition, odor nuisance

title: New reaction route for bio-based adiponitrile production: Towards the rational design of the reactants and reaction pathways
reasoning: The abstract describes a novel synthetic strategy for adiponitrile production using biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, which avoids the safety risks and pollution issues associated with current methods involving acrylonitrile. It explicitly states that this new method is green, sustainable, and safer compared to the traditional acrylonitrile-based processes.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards specifically associated with acrylonitrile. It mentions that the production processes involve highly toxic raw materials and safety concerns, but does not explicitly attribute these harms to acrylonitrile itself.

title: Material Evaluation and Selection Criteria for 3D Printing
reasoning: The abstract compares several 3D printing filaments and explicitly rules out Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene (ABS) due to low chemical resistance and unsuitability for biochemical environments. It selects Polylactic Acid (PLA), Polyethylene Terephthalate Glycol (PETG), and Thermoplastic Polyurethane (TPU) for different parts based on superior properties. This implies these materials are safer alternatives to ABS (which contains acrylonitrile) in the context of chemical resistance and biochemical suitability.
alternatives: Polylactic Acid (PLA); Polyethylene Terephthalate Glycol (PETG); Thermoplastic Polyurethane (TPU)

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to acrylonitrile. It only mentions that ABS (Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene) is ruled out due to low chemical resistance and unsuitability for biochemistry environments, but does not specify any toxicity, persistence, bioaccumulation, or other hazards.

title: Biomarkers of Toxicant Exposure among Youth in Canada, England, and the United States Who Vape and/or Smoke Tobacco or Do Neither
reasoning: The abstract compares toxicant exposure between youth who vape, smoke, or do neither, noting that exclusive vaping is associated with lower exposure to acrylonitrile compared to smoking or dual use. This indicates that vaping is a safer alternative to smoking acrylonitrile-containing tobacco products in terms of acrylonitrile exposure.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text discusses exposure levels to acrylonitrile among youth who vape, smoke, or both, but does not explicitly state any harms or hazards associated with acrylonitrile.
